Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Collaborative Research - Granular Activated Carbon Supported Gold and Palladium Bimetals Catalysts for Sustainable Water Treatment

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1507707
Jiao

1508115
Tratnyek

A team of researchers propose to develop granular activated carbon supported bimetal catalysts that integrate both physic-sorption and catalytic decomposition capabilities to achieve sustainable water treatment. The objective of the proposed project is to design and fabricate a novel class of granular activated carbon-supported palladium-metal (bimetal) catalysts that provides rapid contaminant degradation without accumulation of problematic by-products or significant susceptibility to poisoning (loss of catalytic activity) by common components of natural water.

This project takes advantage of the fact that catalytic hydrodehalogenation and hydrodeoxygenation by palladium (Pd) and Pd-based bimetal catalysts are capable of transforming various classes of organic contaminants to harmless products, this proposed research is focused on developing Pd-M bimetal catalysts where M represents gold (Au), copper (Cu), and indium (In) to achieve catalytic reductive transformation of priority drinking water contaminants such as halogenated organics, oxyanions, and nitrosamines. The PIs preliminary results show that the types of catalysts proposed to study can produce very rapid hydrodehalogenation of trichloroethene as well as hydrogenation of other model contaminants. In the proposed research, a green chemistry synthesis process will be developed. The link between catalyst structure and performance will be systematically investigated with catalysts designed to test specific catalytic mechanisms. Structures of Pd-M hybridized with both perfect graphene and defect-rich graphene in place of granular activated carbon will be modeled to determine the optimal surface structures, charge transfer mechanisms, electronic properties, and energetic distributions. The kinetics of contaminant reduction by such catalysts will be systematically quantified and a practical but rigorous kinetic model will be developed to compare these types of catalysts across a broad range of conditions. The sensitivity of these catalysts to inactivation by known poisons of noble metal catalysts (e.g., sulfide and chloride) common in water treatment will be evaluated and considered in optimization of the catalyst designs. In addition to advancing the technology of water treatment by catalytic hydrogenation processes, this proposed research will contribute to the training of new researchers and practitioners in the field. The PIS will reach out to water service professionals through a series of planned workshops at Clackamas Community College, which has a strong training program for water treatment engineers. Outreach activities to the general public for the demonstration of the sustainable water treatment through collaboration with the Oregon Museum of Science & Industry, a local leader in informal education, are also planned. Furthermore, we are committed to recruiting minority and female graduate students to participate in this proposed research.

Institution.Name: Oregon Health & Science University
Institution.StreetAddress: 3181 S W Sam Jackson Park Rd

POR.DRECONTENT:
The completion and success of this funded project with respect to the intellectual merit and broader impacts are briefly summarized below.

Palladium (Pd) and gold (Au) nanoparticles (NPs) hybridized on carbon supports were designed, fabricated, and tested as catalysts for the removal of chemical contaminants from water. The catalyst materials were synthesized using a simple, environmentally friendly, green chemistry process. The resulting materials were further optimized by systematically investigating the synthesis parameters, including chemical precursor type, ratios of Pd and Au, reaction temperatures, reaction times, and type of carbon substrate. More than a thousand samples were synthesized and characterized during the project. A comparison between the as-made Pd/Au/carbon catalysts and the corresponding commercial Pd on carbon catalysts was carried out. The results showed that the Pd/Au/Carbon catalysts developed by this research are superior to the commercially available Pd/Carbon catalysts with respect to the contaminant-degradation rates and cost-effectiveness. Furthermore, the key findings of this project suggest that both graphene and granular activated carbon (GAC) are suitable carbon supports for the sustainable hydrodehalogenation (HDH) of aqueous trichloroethylene (TCE).

The high reaction rates of our Pd/Au/Carbon catalysts were attributed to the unique combination of the high surface area and adsorbent nature of the carbon supports with the chemical potency of the Pd/Au NPs. The essential catalytic process is that the carbon support attracts TCE to its surface, which is anchored with Pd/Au NPs that break down the contaminant. This enables the developed Pd/Au/Carbon catalyst to be more effective than those of corresponding commercial catalysts. The specific role of Pd and Au NPs is that Pd acts as a catalyst to break down TCE, while Au acts as a strong promoter of the catalytic activity of Pd. In most cases, the kinetics of contaminant removal were pseudo-first order, and the products detected were consistent with HDH for removal of TCE. The developed catalysts also degrade other VOCs such as carbon tetrachloride and 1,2,3-trichloropropane. 

Regarding the broader impacts of this project, the synthesis technique and technology developed by this research, especially the ability to control the size, shape and crystallinity of the nanoparticles (NPs), have shown the potential impacts in other disciplines such as to make high-quality gas and chemical sensors, electrodes, high-performance supercapacitors, fuel cells and other electronic devices. Specifically, the following examples are the results of the impacts of this funded project. 

(a)   Synthesis of photocatalysts and development of a novel system for water purification. The PI and her former PhD student have just received the NSF I-Corps funding for the commercialization of the technique that was developed during this student’s PhD dissertation research. The PI serves as the Technique Leader (TL) for this grant while her former PhD student is the Entrepreneur Leader (EL) who formed his own company for this endeavor. 

(b)   Synthesis of magnetic nanoparticles on carbon substrates for nanoelectronics applications. Currently, preliminary investigation is under the way and is supported by other resources. It is expected that a full proposal will be developed to be submitted to NSF/DMR.

(c)    Highly related to this funded research, one student has completed her PhD degree; one student has completed his MS degree. Both of them are currently employed by a high-tech company after their graduation. Two undergraduate students who have actively participated in this research for more than two years have competed their BS degrees. Both of them have received scholarships from high-ranking universities and are currently pursuing their graduate studies in these universities. One high school female student who has participated in this project last summer has been accepted by a high-ranking university to pursue her bachelor’s degree in Chemical Engineering. She stated that her decision to pursue Chemical Engineering as a major is attributed to her involvement in this funded project.

(d)   The dissemination activities of the results for this funded project are multifold. These are demonstrated by the student’s PhD dissertations, MS theses, conference presentations and journal publications. In the duration of the four years of this project, we have published more than a dozen papers in peer-reviewed journals and conference proceedings. The PIs of this project have been invited to give speeches at national and international conferences, workshops, and seminars. The graduate and undergraduate students involved in this project also presented their research at different conferences.

 


Last Modified: 09/30/2019
Modified by: Paul G Tratnyek

In the duration of the four years of this project, we have published more than a dozen papers in peer-reviewed journals and conference proceedings. The PIs of this project have been invited to give speeches at national and international conferences, workshops, and seminars.
